A man at a point P on the shore of a circular lake of radius 1 mile wants to reach the point Q on the shore diametrically opposite P (Fig. 16-5). He can row 1.5 miles per hour and walk 3 miles per hour. At what angle $\theta $ ($0<\theta < \pi /2$) to the diameter PQ should he row in order to minimize the time required to reach Q? <image 1>

A. $\theta = \pi /2$
B. $\theta = \pi /3$
C. $\theta = \pi $
D. $\theta = 2\pi $

To minimize the time required to reach point Q, the man should row at the speed of 1.5 miles per hour and walk at the speed of 3 miles per hour. The total speed of the man is the sum of his rowing speed and his walking speed, which is 1.5 + 3 = 4.5 miles per hour.

The distance to reach point Q is the diameter of the lake, which is 2 miles. The time required to reach point Q can be calculated using the formula:

\[ \text{Time} = \frac{\text{Distance}}{\text{Speed}} \]

Substituting the given values:

\[ \text{Time} = \frac{2}{4.5} \approx 0.444 \text{ hours} \]

To minimize the time, the man should row at the speed of 1.5 miles per hour. The time required to row 1.5 miles at 1.5 miles per hour is:

\[ \text{Time} = \frac{1.5}{1.5} = 1 \text{ hour} \]

Therefore, the angle $\theta$ to the diameter PQ that the man should row in order to minimize the time required to reach Q is $\theta = \pi / 2$.

The correct answer is:

A. $\theta = \pi / 2$
